title.rendered: Hydrangea Arborescens – Uses, Dosage, Side Effects, Composition And More

content.rendered:
What is Hydrangea Arborescens?

Hydrangea arborescens, commonly referred to as smooth hydrangea or sevenbark, belongs to the Hydrangeaceae family. This deciduous shrub typically reaches heights of up to 2 meters (7 feet) and features multiple stems. It primarily grows in the eastern regions of the United States. The flowering period extends from May to July, showcasing its blooms.

The plant produces fruit in the form of a ribbed, brown capsule that measures around 2 millimeters in length. Its leaves are sizable, ranging from 8 to 18 centimeters long, and are arranged oppositely. These ovate leaves have serrated edges and are deciduous, with the underside being smooth or sparsely covered with fine hairs, presenting a green appearance; any trichomes are concentrated along the midrib and major veins.

Hydrangea Arborescens Chemical Constituents

Hydrangea arborescens contains several chemical constituents that contribute to its medicinal properties in the treatment of various medications. These chemical constituents function together to provide hydrangea arborescens with its therapeutic properties, especially in the treatment of urinary and kidney-related issues.

Hydrangin is a glucoside that is believed to have diuretic properties, isohydrangin, saponins, and flavonoids, which have antioxidant activity and can help protect cells from damage. Phytosterols is a plant-derived sterols that can have cholesterol-lowering effects.

Cyanogenic Glycosides release small amounts of hydrogen cyanide when metabolized, which may contribute to the plant’s biological effects. Tannins are polyphenolic compounds that can have astringent properties.

Hydrangea Arborescens Preparation

Hydrangea arborescens is prepared by scientists in several forms, depending on its intended use, particularly in herbal or homeopathic medicine. These methods of preparation offer different ways to use hydrangea arborescens for its medicinal benefits across the studies, depending on the desired form and ease of use.

  • Herbal Infusion (Tea): Dried hydrangea arborescens root or leaves, about 1-2 teaspoons and 1 cup of boiling water is required to prepare the herbal infusion or tea of hydrangea arborescens. To prepare it, the dried roots or leaves are placed into a cup or teapot, then pour boiling water over the herb. It is covered and steeped for about 10-15 minutes. And then, the mixture is strained.
  • Tincture: The tincture of hydrangea arborescens is prepared by using fresh or dried Hydrangea arborescens root and alcohol or glycerin. The fresh roots are finely chopped and placed in a clean, dry jar. Pour alcohol or glycerin over the root and keep submerged completely. Seal the jar and put it in a cool, dark place for about 4-6 weeks. Then, strain the liquid and keep it in a bottle.
  • Powder: It is made by using dried hydrangea arborescens root. The dried root is ground into a fine powder using a grinder, and then the powder is encapsulated for further use.

Hydrangea Arborescens Mother Tincture

Hydrangea arborescens mother tincture is a homeopathic medicine that is effective in treating certain medical conditions like an enlarged prostate and frequent urination. It is primarily used for managing symptoms related to kidney stones and also reduces soreness around the kidney area, as well as blood in the urine. Here are the advantages of using hydrangea arborescens mother tincture:

  • Hydrangea arborescens mother tincture treats prostate enlargement and urinary issues
  • Reduces the presence of white amorphous salts in the urine
  • It avoids the formation of kidney stones and eases pain from renal stones
  • It decreases the urge to urinate frequently and relieves pain during urination

Benefits of Hydrangea Arborescens

There are multiple benefits of using hydrangea arborescens, and it has a wide history of treating multiple diseases. Here are some benefits of hydrangea arborescens, that are discussed below:

  • Protect Your Kidneys: When a person has certain substances in the blood that can indicate kidney damage. In such cases, hydrangea arborescens is used to lower the blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels significantly.
  • Anti-Inflammatory Properties: Hydrangea arborescens roots contain a compound called coumarin, along with its derivative, skimmin, which consists of anti-inflammatory effects that are used in medical conditions. Hydrangea arborescens root extract is also helpful in preventing inflammatory cells from entering kidney tissue, which decreases the chances of inflammation.
  • Antioxidant Effects: Majorly oxidative stress occurs in the body when there are too many reactive oxygen species (ROS) present, which can lead to tissue damage. Whereas, antioxidants help protect the body against oxidative stress. The chemical compound coumarins present in hydrangea arborescens root have antioxidant properties, which reduce oxidative stress, showing strong antioxidant effects.
  • Lower Blood Sugar Levels: Various studies suggest that skimming present in hydrangea arborescens root reduces insulin resistance and helps control blood sugar levels.
  • Protect Your Liver: Compounds present in hydrangea arborescens stems are used in protecting the liver against liver toxicity.
  • Provide Cancer-Fighting Properties: Hydrangenol, another compound in hydrangeas arborescens, may stop the growth and spread of bladder cancer cells.

What Does Hydrangea Arborescens Treat?

Hydrangea arborescens has been used in traditional medicine widely over the years, and its effectiveness for treating multiple medical conditions has been under research. Here are some diseases that are treated by hydrangea arborescens:

  • Urinary tract infections (UTIs): Hydrangea arborescens treats urinary tract infections, as it acts as a diuretic and antiseptic agent. Tannins and flavonoids present in hydrangea arborescens are believed to have antimicrobial properties, which help fight bacterial infections in the urinary system.
  • Kidney stones: The hydrangea arborescens plant has mild diuretic and lithontriptic (stone-breaking) properties, which help the body to flush out kidney stones and prevent their further formation.
  • Inflammation: The anti-inflammatory compounds present in hydrangea arborescens, such as saponins and oleanolic acid, may help reduce inflammation in the body. Hence, it relaxes medical conditions like arthritis, gout, and other inflammatory disorders.
  • Respiratory issues: The diseases like bronchitis, asthma, and coughs are known to be treated by hydrangea arborescens. The anti-inflammatory and expectorant properties of hydrangea arborescens help in soothing the airways and facilitate the removal of mucus.
  • Skin conditions: Various skin conditions, such as eczema, psoriasis, and insect bites, are treated by hydrangea arborescens due to their purported anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial effects.

Hydrangea Arborescens Homeopathic Uses

Hydrangea arborescens has been used in homeopathic medicine to treat a variety of health conditions. As it is a homeopathic medicine, it is always advised to consult with a healthcare professional. Here are the hydrangea arborescens homeopathic medicine uses discussed below:

  • Urinary and Kidney Disorders: It is the most common medicine used by people for treating urinary and kidney-related issues. It is also used to treat kidney stones, cystitis (bladder inflammation), urethritis (urethra inflammation), and pyelonephritis (kidney inflammation). It functions by dissolving and expelling kidney stones and soothes and reduces inflammation in the urinary tract due to its homeopathic preparation.
  • Prostate Problems: It is used to treat prostate-related issues, such as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and prostatitis. This has a calming and restorative effect on the prostate gland, reducing the swelling, pain, and difficulty with urination.
  • Rheumatic and Arthritic Conditions: It is used to treat various forms of rheumatism, arthritis, and joint pain. The anti-inflammatory properties help in reducing medical conditions like gout, osteoarthritis, and rheumatoid arthritis. Hydrangea arborescens mostly cure the joint pain which occurs during the cold and damp weather
  • Respiratory Issues: In homeopathy, bronchitis, chronic cough, and asthma are treated by hydrangea arborescens. It provides a soothing and expectorant effect, helping to loosen and expel mucus from the respiratory system.
  • Skin Conditions: Various skin conditions, such as eczema, psoriasis, and skin rashes are treated by the use of hydrangea arborescens. Its anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties are helpful in skin irritation and promote healing.

Hydrangea Arborescens Dosage

The dosage of hydrangea arborescens depends on multiple factors, such as the methods of preparation and the specific health condition being treated with it.

  • The tincture of hydrangea arborescens is taken 10-30 drops diluted in water about 2-3 times daily.
  • The herbal infusion (Tea) is taken about 1-2 cups per day.
  • 1-2 capsules of hydrangea arborescens are taken 1-2 times daily, depending on the strength of the capsules (usually 500 mg each).
  • 1-2 grams of hydrangea arborescens powder can be taken daily or mixed with water, juice, or another beverage.

Hydrangea Arborescens Dosage For Adults

The recommended dosage of hydrangea arborescens depends on the age, medical conditions, method of preparation, and overall health of the adult consuming it.

  • 10-30 drops of tincture of hydrangea arborescens is diluted in water and taken 2-3 times daily.
  • 1-2 cups per day of herbal infusion or tea is taken. 1-2 capsules (usually 500 mg each) of hydrangea arborescens can be taken 1-2 times daily.
  • 1-2 grams of hydrangea arborescens can be taken daily that is mixed with water or another beverage. It is always advised to consult with a doctor before consuming it.

Hydrangea Arborescens Dosage for Children

It is generally advised to not give hydrangea arborescens to the children in the first place, but when recommended by the doctor, it should be given with appropriate dosage. The appropriate dosage of hydrangea arborescens can depend on the child’s age, weight, and specific health needs.

  • Generally, the dosage of hydrangea arborescens is much lower than for adults, mostly 2-10 drops of tincture diluted in water taken 1-2 times daily, depending on the child’s age and weight.
  • For children, a very mild tea of hydrangea arborescens can be given, using 1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon of dried root or leaves per cup of water that too 1-2 times daily.

Who Should Avoid Hydrangea Arborescens?

While hydrangea arborescens is widely used in the medicinal field, it can have some side effects or cause certain complications in individuals. Hence, it is important to learn about them before consuming them.

  • Pregnant and breastfeeding women: Due to a lack of scientific data on its safety during these physiological states of pregnancy and breastfeeding of a woman, it is advised to avoid its usage. As it may have some potentially adverse effects on the developing fetus or nursing infant.
  • Children and infants: The safety of the use of hydrangea arborescens is not well researched in the case of children’s usage. And, it also has some risks of potential toxicity in their cases.
  • Individuals with kidney or liver disease: Hydrangea arborescens is primarily metabolized and excreted through the kidneys and liver. Hence, people suffering from pre-existing kidney or liver conditions may be at a higher risk of adverse effects and might also risk their organ functioning.

Potential Side Effects Of Using Hydrangea Arborescens

  • In some rare cases, gastrointestinal side effects, such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, especially when taken in large doses, can be a case while consuming hydrangea arborescens.
  • Certain chemical constituents of the hydrangea arborescens plant might cause a level of irritation in the stomach and overall digestive system.
  • In some rare cases, consuming hydrangea arborescens might also cause allergic reactions, including skin rashes, hives, and respiratory distress.

FAQs

  • Is homeopathic Hydrangea arborescens safe?

    The safety of homeopathic hydrangea arborescens is still under research, as there are some possible risks and concerns, but also some indications that it may be relatively safe when used appropriately under strict guidance and the right dosage.

  • How to give Hydrangea arborescens to babies?

    It is mostly avoided to administer hydrangea arborescens to babies, and if done, it should be done with extreme caution and only under the guidance of a qualified healthcare provider, such as a pediatrician or herbalist.

  • How does Hydrangea arborescens work?

    The chemical compounds present in hydrangea arborescens may lead to increased urine production, which is beneficial for certain urinary tract issues.

  • How long does Hydrangea arborescens take to work?

    The time taken by hydrangea arborescens to show effects can vary depending on the individual, the condition being treated, and the form in which it is taken, it can range from about a few hours to a day even.

  • Can Hydrangea arborescens be taken daily?

    Yes, hydrangea arborescens can be taken daily, but it should be done with caution and under the guidance of a healthcare provider.

  • What is Hydrangea arborescens used to treat?

    Hydrangea arborescens is a medication used to treat and prevent many medical conditions like enlarged prostate, prostate infections, bladder infections, urethral infections, kidney stones, and hay fever.

  • What is Hydrangea arborescens used for in homeopathy?

    In homeopathy, people use hydrangea for bladder infections, prostate infections, enlarged prostate, kidney stones, and other medical conditions.

  • What are the benefits of Hydrangea arborescens tonic?

    Hydrangea arborescens tonic is often used in herbal medicine for its various health benefits such as help with kidney and bladder issues, enlarged prostate, and hay fever.

  • How do you use Hydrangea arborescens mother tincture?

    Hydrangea arborescens mother tincture is a concentrated herbal extract used in homeopathy for issues related to the urinary tract and kidneys. Add the prescribed number of drops of hydrangea arborescens mother tincture to a small amount of water, usually about 1/4 to 1/2 cup. This dilutes the tincture and makes it easier to consume.
